threads.sub: Does the fully auto mode of a weapon really matter in real combat?
threads.com:
I've heard that while many people like to use fully automatic weapons in video games, almost no one does so in real combat. Because the bullet recoil in full auto mode will make you miss anything. And ammunition is consumed too quickly, and it's easy to run short of bullets.
So what is the use of full-automatic mode in real combat?

The recoil isn't that intense.
I only ever used burst in combat once and that was to provide suppressing fire.
Generally, I would use single shot because I didn't know how long a given fight may last and so I saved my ammunition.

threads.sub: Why there are no optic sights ever used on AKs in Ukraine?
threads.com:
Since war in Ukraine started only time I've seen photos of someone not using basic iron sights on AK, was when first wave of Kadyrov's tiktok Chechens bringed their fancy rifles with them.

Even if AK-12 has rail on it that screams for using optics, it's always used with iron sights (pic related). I know rail in on AK-12 is useless, but these iron sights are still attached to it, so why not using something more sophisticated? Or even some cheap red dot, that would be adequate fit for cheap rail (and cheap Russian army in general).

Even when some Specnaz guys were using their customized AK-74M, they usually stick to iron sights. I've heard it's to keep it as low-profile as possible (something Russians learned from Simo Hayha), but is this serious, or just another example of russian coping mechanism and true reason is that Russian army is too cheap to buy even it's most elite soldiers more advanced sights?

Also, Ukrainians aren't using optic sights on their AKs as well, despite using them on everything else?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56123065
>Scorpion
From my experience, Scorpions can be picky with hollow points. Stribogs too. A friend of mine could only get Hornady Critical Defense to reliably feed 100% in his Stribog. Other HPs would experience the occasional problem. The Critical Defense rounds have a more rounded nose, which is probably why they fed so well. That said, the Stribog has had magazine issues ever since they were first released. They're on their 3rd magazine design.

You're probably right about Colt mags vs Glock mags. I have an AR-9 made by Foxtrot Mike that uses Glock mags, and after some modifications (new buffer and carbine buffer spring) it seems to feed Gold Dots reliably despite the poor feed cone on the barrel. I would need to fire more Gold Dots to be comfortable with it as a home defense gun.

The B&T APC9 feeds Gold Dots and HSTs reliably without any modifications, in my short time shooting one owned by someone else. However, it's a $3k gun.

I'm still of the opinion that short barreled 300 BLK guns have obsoleted 9mm PCCs, but the reality is that 9mm defense rounds are cheaper and more plentiful, and the average person looking for a home defense gun isn't going to care about how well 300 BLK suppresses, because they're not going to buy a suppressor. That said, anyone with a 9mm PCC should put at least 60 rounds of their home defense load of choice through their gun to ensure no malfunctions occur.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Think it's worth it to get some pic related and seal your unsealed primers and bullets?

Way I see it:
Pros: bullets might hold up better during long-term storage in the humidity and if you're out with them during heavy rain or being dropped into the water

Cons: less reliable gun since it gets gunked up with sealant if you're shooting a lot. During a Vepr torture test I saw, it eventually had a malfunction because of the sealant on the ammunition building up.

Worth it?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56116555
I've thought about doing it for my defensive handloads but I accidentally did a water test with them and they fired just fine.
The accidental water test I conducted was me accidentally dropping my damn speedloader in the toilet and taking 5 or so seconds to get it out of the thankfully clean toilet bowl. I let the rounds sit on a paper towel and shot them a few weeks later and each one fired just fine. I had noticed the powder was dry since I shook the cases shortly after I dropped them and you could hear the powder jumping around. They were .38 Spl 158 gr LSWCHP +P loads I cooked up, with a pretty generous roll crimp. The roll crimp may have helped keep moisture out, but I was expecting most the water would come in through the gap between the primer and the case.
Point being, those rounds probably endured more water than your carry ammo would deal with over the span of a few years. So is sealant necessary? Probably not. But if you wanna use it go ahead.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56116153
Study what other people did. Look at all firearm designs you can find. It’s not like you need to reinvent the wheel, nobody does. Think about design elements one could combine, with a real world application in mind.
If you want to design a weapon for the ground up, I personally would start with something that is mechanically less complicated than a handgun. Think single shot shotgun/rifle.
Look into european artisan gunmaker literature.
Learn how to machine and use classical metal/wood working tools.
Alternatively get into CNC and CAD.

Dawn of Black Friday deals edition

Resource on what these spec terminology mean
https://www.nite-walker.com/post/2019/11/21/specs-for-dummies-101
https://apollogearco.com/blogs/news/night-vision-specs-explained
https://gloomgroup.com/blogs/night-vision-info/night-vision-specifications-understanding-what-they-mean

You shouldn't be chasing for spec values but they do exist and if you wanted to know what "better spec" values are there's a way to know which unit is desirable over another.
Most retailers won't post this info as they build NVDs to order, first come first serve, and depending on their grading scale of high, mid, low tier it may differ from retailers. If a retailer offer a “ready to ship” fully built units they will list the spec values. Hand select is an option from retailers that will try to match to your spec requirements.

Some reputable retailers:
https://www.jrhenterprises.com/
https://nvisionoptics.com/
https://www.customnightvision.com/
https://gooningear.com/
https://apollogearco.com
https://blackphasetactical.com/
https://steeleindustries.com/

SNR: signal to noise ratio, the amount of signal the tube can make compared to the noise
EBI: equivalent background information, how much false image appears in the screen through which the actual image has to show, sort of a noise floor of sorts
Halo: How big the circle of bloom is around lights
Photocathode Sensitivity: How sensitive the photocathode is
LP Resolution: Line pair res of the center of the image as measure against a standardized chart

If one spec is shit it negates the rest, if you have a halo of 2.0 it kinda fucks on an EBI of 0.20 if you want to do any kind of shooting and it's all a balance game

The numbers to meet or beat are
EBI under 1, preferably under 0.6 being great, 0.1 is gucci
Halo under 1, anything under 0.7 is awesome
SNR, over 25 anything over 30 is gucci
Photocathode, 1900+ is pretty great, 2500+ is stellar
Resolution of 64+ is good, 72+ is gucci

threads.com: Is it possible to buy all gun parts online and assemble a gun without needing papers? Why isn't everyone doing it?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56116470
>Is it possible to buy all gun parts online and assemble a gun without needing papers? Why isn't everyone doing it?
>all parts
No.

>enough parts that you need to do a couple hours of machining, assembly, and fitting
Yep.

>why isn't everyone doing it
Because even with piss-easy guns like the Glock clones and AR-15, it's still detailed and fiddly work that takes either several hundred dollars in specialized tooling and a bit or precision, or around a hundred bucks in tools and a LOT more precise work. It's very easy to fuck it up, at which point you need to buy more parts.
Or you can just buy a cheap-ass gun that does essentially the same shit (a Taurus, a PSA blem gun, a low-end 10-22). If you already have machining experience and are into it, then it's a fun project that will save you money and time over buying a pre-built weapon and customizing it. It's also a good way of working out how a gun actually works if you want to make something else down the road. Otherwise, building your own gun costs around $3-500 more than just buying an equivalent weapon off the shelf not counting labor. Buying a stripped lower (which IS regulated) and then building a weapon on top of it usually costs a bit less than machining an 80% but still more than off-the-rack.

>inb4 3dp guns
Those take about the same amount of time, tools cost, and work as a forged 80% once you know what you're doing with the printer. And it takes quite a bit longer to get the printer working correctly to build a safe gun and learn how to set it up than it does to learn how to run a jigged plunge router or drill press and files with a vise. Plus plastic lowers have a bad habit of wallowing out pin holes and such if you fuck up while assembling, though the recovery costs are cheaper than with an 80%.

>roads made out of corpses
Why is it called the Road of Bones?
The road is commonly known as the Road of Bones. The nickname speaks to its tragic history. It was built by the hundreds of thousands of political prisoners who were exiled to the region’s gulags under the Stalin regime from the 1930s to the 1950s, under Dalstroy construction directorate. The first stretch was built by the inmates of the Sevvostlag labor camp in 1932. The work was done with very rudimentary methods, such as shovels and wheelbarrows. The construction continued (by inmates of gulag camps) until 1953. Thousands were shot for not working hard enough, while others died from the gulags’ brutal conditions. The cold was another killer: with temperatures recorded as low as some -70C, the Kolyma is located in the world’s coldest inhabited area. Many of the dead simply were buried beneath the road’s foundations. It is said that the Kolyma Highway cost one death for every meter of road built. In fact, to circulate on it involves traveling over a colossal mass grave that houses many thousands of corpses. The road is treated as a memorial, as the bones of the estimated 250,000–1,000,000 people who died while constructing it were laid beneath or around the road. The ruins of that cruel era are still visible today.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: Cool obscure guns from the 1400s to 1700s
threads.com:
The early modern era has a TON of clockpunk-looking weapon concepts that were actually produced and did in fact work (suck it, Leo). Unfortunately the sheer expense and delicacy of them rendered them impractical for mass-deployment (no mass produced parts before the Industrial Revolution), leaving them as toys of nobles (or, occasionally, a tool for super-elite soldiers) while the armies continued to make do with muzzle-loading muskets and cannons, swords, and polearms. One great example is the Kalthoff repeater which is familiar to many here.

It was first produced in the 1620s, at which time the average soldier was still using either a pike or a matchlock musket/arquebus as their primary arm. Only the elites got flintlock firearms. With paper cartridges, flintlocks could be expected to hit firing rates of 3-4 per minute in the hands of a skilled soldier, compared to 1-2 for a matchlock.

The Kalthoff shat all over this. It used a flintlock mechanism, but with two big differences from the common rabble. One, it was a breechloader, meaning you didn't have to upend the whole gun to load it. Two, it had a sliding box-breech loading mechanism that could hold up to 30 shots and push them into place. With this it could obtain a firing rate of over 30 rounds per minute, with comparatively quick reload. It was also decently reliable.

The downside: not only was it ruinously expensive, but it was so complex that if it ever broke, it would require a master gunsmith to repair it. And even he'd need some time to do so. Probably only a few hundred were ever made, and they only saw use by one military unit, the Scanian Guard. Similar weapons like the Klett and Dorttlo popped up shortly after with the same flaws.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

Those measure in volumetric grains. 1 cc equals 15.4 volumetric grains. Use a lee powder charge chart that converts known powders from cc to grains by weight. Then you can convert your measures grain by volume to cubic centimeters then to grains by weight.

Or just buy a set of powder dippers you fucking sperg.

Assuming you calibrate your measure by weighing 10 throws and averaging, I can't imagine it's any different than any other volumetric measurement, but I suppose it's possible that it will be less precise for you based on some workflow concern or something. I really like the RCBS micrometer powder measure, I can throw 10 drops within a tenth of a grain of each other as fast as I can get a case in position to catch the powder, it's fast and smooth and consistent.

I can't imagine that the repurposed BP measure is going to be as fast or as convenient.
